subject: Re: [junit] testing return;
msgSnippet: ... There is no possible way that ctxIn can be null. -- J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info Your guide to software craftsmanship JUnit Recipes:
messageBody:
Kamal Ahmed wrote:
> Hi,
>
> In the following method, How do I test if return is being executed, and
> control returns to the calling method, which in this case is setAuditContext
>
> public synchronized void setAuditContext(final Stack<LockedValue> context) {
> Stack<LockedValue> ctxIn = new Stack<LockedValue>();
> ctxIn.addAll(context);
>
> if (ctxIn == null && ctx == null) {
> return;
> }
>
> if (ctxIn == null && ctx != null) {
> ctx = null;
> }
>
> I am also using Coverlipse, but the "return" is not being covered by the
> following test method:

There is no possible way that ctxIn can be null.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
Your guide to software craftsmanship
JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
